manualItem.name: quick-intro
manualItem.manualHTML:
Tutorial text will be displayed here, where you are reading these words, in the right frame, while the VegBank content stays in the left frame. If you click a blue link like this info page or this faq, the link will open in the left frame. If you click a green link like the ones at the bottom of this frame, it opens a new tutorial topic here on the right.
Click the header link to see the page that this help topic applies to (this topic will take you to the homepage). Click a green navigation link (next, previous, or tutorial menu), to see a new tutorial topic here on the right. All of this allows you to view the tutorial here and independently control VegBank on the left.
Highlighting is available for browsers with javascript enabled. Click a link (like that one) to highlight a portion of the screen in the left frame. Click the link again if you want to unhighlight it. If you have moved to a different page in the left frame, then highlighting won't work, and will prompt you if you'd like to go to the page that the tutorial is talking about. Then you can try to highlighting again. Clear all highlighting with the unhighlight link at the bottom of all tutorial windows.
To close this tutorial, use the close or exit links at the bottom of each tutorial window. If close doesn't work, press exit. Javascript is required for closing and highlighting.
Press next to start learning about VegBank!

manualItem.name: find-plots
manualItem.manualHTML:
To start finding plots in VegBank, go to The Home Page and look in the Find Plots Section.
Here, you can browse plots, search for plots, and view plots by choosing a state or province from a map. Click one of the next help topics to see more on each of these.

manualItem.name: browse-data
manualItem.manualHTML:
The Browse Data page shows you a sample of the plots in VegBank, listed in different categories. Each category lists a small set of values that represent the largest number of plots. Click the number of plots to see plots, and the values to see more information about it. Under each category, there are links that allow you to see the full set of plots, and hides the other categories.
Where Plots Are lists states and provinces which contain VegBank plots. A map graphically represents the same information, and you can click a state or province in the map to see its plots. A larger map is also available.
People are listed who have contributed to a plot in some way. This could be sampling the plot, being a PI for the project, or classifying the plot to a particular plant community.
Projects group plots that are generally collected in similar areas, over short periods of time, and with the same methodology.
Plants that are found on the most plots are listed.
Communities are listed to which plots have been interpreted. VegBank users make these interpretations, so each plot May have multiple communties assigned to it.
Overview of Data lists how much data is currently stored in VegBank.

manualItem.name: simple-plot-search
manualItem.manualHTML:
The simple plot search will find plots based on one or more of the following:
a state/province name or country in which the plot is found
a plant name that is found in the plot
a community name to which the plot is classified
Leave a field blank if you would like ignore one or more of these. If you fill in more than one box, only plots that match ALL criteria will be found. Case is ignored in this search (Quercus is the same as querus). Use the percent (%) for a wildcard, meaning that you can write part of the name. Tip: Queries are faster without wildcards. Queries that start with a wildcard are slower than those that do not. (%alba is slower than Quercus%, which is slower than Quercus alba.)
Examples:
Search for plots in Kansas.
Search for plots with plant name of Acer rubrum
Search for plots with a community name of Quercus%Acer%
Search for plots in New York with a plant name of Acer%
For help with plot search results, see this topic.

manualItem.name: advanced-plot-search
manualItem.manualHTML:
This searches for plots by location, species present, community type, methodology, and other plot criteria. A simpler search is a good place to start if you're new to VegBank. VegBank will find the plots that match ALL the criteria on this form.
To configure the search (optional), check the boxes by the fields you'd like to search in the "Configure Your Search" box and press the "change query fields" button. Then, VegBank hides the list of fields to get them out of the way. You can show them again to adjust which fields are shown (careful, this resets the form). Scroll down past this box after configuration, or if you'd like to skip this step.
Fill in the query fields that you'd like to search by, using the MM/DD/YYYY format (like 01/15/2005) for dates and percent (%) for wildcard in text fields. @Tut_StdSearchAdvice@ Press the search button at the bottom of the page to start your search.
If plants or communities are part of your search, there are several rows of entries for each. You can use this to specify multiple plants that must be present or multiple community names that you want your plots to match.
Validation: If you enter dates or numbers that are in a format VegBank doesn't recognize, you'll get a popup message saying so. The problem field will be highlighted. Please fix that entry and press "search" again.
For help with plot search results, see this topic.

manualItem.name: map-of-plots
manualItem.manualHTML:
A map of plots is available on the Home Page and a larger version exists as well. The map shows the number of plots in each state or province in North America, grouping by colors.
Click a state or province to see the plots in it. This map is updated regularly, but not automatically. If the map isn't updated accurately, please contact us to let us know.

manualItem.name: plot-search-results
manualItem.manualHTML:
The Plot Search Results (the above link is an example) are displayed any time you search for plots (from the map, the list of plots for a particular plant, project, method, etc.). If you used the Advanced Plot Search, then these results will be configured according the the fields shown there. Otherwise, the default set of fields will appear.
Most of the time, a message will appear at the top of the screen, identifying what search criteria were used to find the plots listed below. If no message appears, you probably clicked a simple link from a project, plant, etc. to see the plots that are connected to it.
The headers on the first row sometimes show more than one field that will appear below. If so, the headers are separated by a horizontal line. Each plot is represented by one shaded row under the headers. This is only a short summary of the plot, click the "plot detail" link on a row to see the full details of a plot. Only some plants are listed in this view. There are many links to more detail throughout this and all views of VegBank data.
You can add plots to your datacart, which allows you to collect plots from different query results. You can also download plots in your datacart.
If many plots matched your search, the results may be paginated. Click the different page numbers to move through your results.

manualItem.name: view-plot-details
manualItem.manualHTML:
Link to an example plot detail page with the this link. This view shows almost all of the information about a plot in VegBank. There are many fields, and you can show or hide field information to show links to the data dictionary which describes each field in detail. You can also hover over a field name with your cursor and some information is displayed as a tool tip.
The information about the whole plot is listed on the left , and the plants found on this plot are listed on the right.
There are three different options for viewing plants: by strata, overall cover, and both. Some plots have species listed only by stratum, some have only listings by overall cover. Some have both. VegBank shows strata by default if strata exist for a plot. If you show both stratum records and overall cover, the overall cover records will have -all- listed as their stratum. Click a plant name to see more information about it, and/or to interpret the species to a plant concept.
The plant view can be sorted by clicking a green header row. The initial sort order can be recreated by clicking the first "ord" column. The intial order attempts to list the tallest stratum first, then by decreasing cover values within each stratum.
You can also add or remove this plot from the datacart by clicking the datacart link in the upper left.

manualItem.name: datacart-building
manualItem.manualHTML:
The Datacart is an online shopping cart (without fees!). You can add or remove plots from the plot search results page and the plot detail view. Click one of those links as an example.
Add plots to the datacart that you are interested in by clicking the image. Then that area is highlighted and the number of items in your datacart increases at the top of the screen. To remove an item, click the image. You can add all plots on a page, or all the search results to the datacart with links at the top of the Plot Search Results page.
To view or download the plots in your datacart, press download X items on the left side of the header.

manualItem.name: view-datacart
manualItem.manualHTML:
To view the plots in your datacart, press download X items on any page in VegBank. For how to build a datacart (add plots to it), see the previous topic.
Once you have pressed the download link, you'll see the contents of your datacart. If you have a many plots in the datacart, it may be displayed over several pages. When viewing your datacart, you can link to each plot in the datacart, and you can remove (and add back) any plots in the datacart. (But you will permanently remove plots if you click a link after removing a plot. Removing plots may also confuse the pager.)
If you'd like to download your datacart, press the Download link at the top of this page.

manualItem.name: download-datacart
manualItem.manualHTML:
If you'd like to download your datacart, press the Download link at the top of the datacart page, after adding some plots to the datacart.
VegBank plans to offer several different download files formats, which are described on the download page. Currently, only the most popular and useful file format, the .csv (spreadsheet) download is available. We have recently greatly increased the speed of this download.

manualItem.name: recently-added-plots
manualItem.manualHTML: The Home Page shows a list of recently added plots . Projects with newly added plots are listed, with the most recently added plots listed first. This is designed to inform VegBank users about the new data that is coming online.

manualItem.name: header
manualItem.manualHTML:
The VegBank Header is available from all pages in VegBank. From the header, you can search for data, and link to our most popular and userful pages.
To Search for data from the header, fill in the form on the left . You can look for a particular type of data using the drop down menu. Fill in a word or words that describe what you're looking for (a plant name, person name, method name, location, etc.) and press go. This search uses the General Search Engine, and more about how it works can be seen on that help topic.
To Navigate to popular VegBank pages, use the links next to the header search. . Also, use the down down menu at the top of the screen.

manualItem.name: plant-taxa
manualItem.manualHTML: The Plant Taxa of the Home Page links you to pages in VegBank that have to do with plants. Be sure to see the first link, "What is a plant concept?" for information about how VegBank defines plant concepts. Press next to see more information about the links listed here.

manualItem.name: browse-plants
manualItem.manualHTML:
This allows you to browse through the plants in VegBank. You can browse alphabetically, by the first letter of the plant names. The plants will be shown in the Plant Summary format.
You can also browse by hierarchy, starting with the Plantae Kingdom or a family of your choice. The plants will be shown in the Plant Detail format.

manualItem.name: search-for-plants
manualItem.manualHTML:
This searches for plant concepts in VegBank, by name or some portion of a name, as well as other plant attributes.
Please see the overview of plant taxonomy as handled by VegBank. Note: assertions are equivalent to concepts in that article.
Fill in any part of the plant search form and press the search button. @Tut_StdSearchAdvice@
The first (and most important) field is plant name . You can search for all words listed, any word listed, or match the string by selecting the equivalent radio button. The wildcard, %, is only valid for the exact match.
Also note that by default, the minimum number of plots is 1. Set this to 0 if you want to find all plants, even those that are not on any VegBank plots.
Examples:
plant name = Acer rubrum with an match all words
plant name = Magnolia Quercus with match any word AND type of name=Scientific
plant name = Carex% with exact match AND with a minimum of 20 plots
plant name = table%pine with exact match

manualItem.name: view-plant-summary
manualItem.manualHTML:
This page shows brief summaries of one or more plant concepts. The results of most plant searches lead to this page. Most of the time, a message will appear telling you what you searched for.
The header row allows sorting by clicking on any green underlined header. Click again to sort descending.
Each row represents one plant, and you can see more details with the link in the first column. If you are viewing many plants, they may be paginated across several pages.

manualItem.name: view-plant-detail
manualItem.manualHTML:
This page shows details of one or more plant concepts. The results of a few plant searches lead to this page, such as Browse Plants by Hierarchy. Sometimes, a message will appear telling you what you searched for.
Each area between beige banners represent one plant. The area in white represents static information about the plant, which is independent of party. The Concept definition is the name combined with the reference in which the name is described. These are listed here, as is a link to plots in which this plant is observed.
The area in grey represents information that is part of one party perspective, that is someone's opinion about a plant (whether or not it is accepted, where in the hierarchy it fits, names to call it, and synonyms). Here, you can navigate throughout the hierarchy (to parents and children) with the parent and children links. Different people and organizations have different opinions about which plants should be grouped under which, thus the hierarchy is party-dependent. You can also link to synonyms and the USDA Plants website for plants with a USDA Party Perspective and a code.
Please note that it is possible for more than one party perspective to be listed per plant.

manualItem.name: submit-plants
manualItem.manualHTML:
Currently, it is only possible to submit plants to VegBank through the XML Loader. We plan to implement online forms in the future.
Generally, it is not necessary to submit many new plots to VegBank, as the entire USDA Plants dataset has already been loaded. If you have plants outside North America, or new species to science (or newly defined plant concepts), you will have to add these using VegBranch. For instructions on loading XML into VegBank, please see the Submit Plots topic. Please Note that to add any data to VegBank, or to annotate data, you will need to be registered and certified.

manualItem.name: plant-communities
manualItem.manualHTML: The Plant Communities Section of the Home Page (Plant Communities are also called Community Types) links you to pages in VegBank that have to do with communities. Be sure to see the first link: What is a community? if you're not familiar with what communities are, or how VegBank defines them. Press next to see more information about the links listed here.

manualItem.name: search-for-communities
manualItem.manualHTML:
This searches for communities in VegBank, by name or some portion of a name, or by other attributes of a community, such as level, name type, or party.
Please see the overview of plant taxonomy for details about concept-based taxonomy, which applies to both plants and communities in VegBank. Note: assertions are equivalent to concepts in that article.
Fill in any part of this form and press the search button. @Tut_StdSearchAdvice@
The first (and most important) field is community name . You can search for all words listed, any word listed, or match the string by selecting the equivalent radio button. The wildcard, %, is only valid for the exact match.
Also note that by default, the minimum number of plots is 1. Set this to 0 if you want to find all communities, even those without plots associated with them.
Example searches:
community name = Magnolia Quercus with match any word (for all communities with either Magnolia or Quercus in the name
community name = Magnolia Quercus with match all words (for all communities with both Magnolia and Quercus in the name
community name = Quercus with match all words AND Community Level of AllianceAND with a minimum of 0 plots
community name = Juniper%horizon% with an exact match AND with a minimum of 0 plots(for all communities starting with Juniper and then containing horizon)
Party = Jennings, Michael with at least 1 plot (for all communities which have a party perspective by Michael Jennings )

manualItem.name: view-comm-summary
manualItem.manualHTML:
This page shows brief summaries of one or more community concepts. The results of most community searches lead to this page. Most of the time, a message will appear telling you what you searched for.
The header row allows sorting by clicking on any green underlined header. Click again to sort descending.
Each row represents one community, and you can see more details with the link in the first column. If you are viewing many communities, they may be paginated across several pages.

manualItem.name: view-comm-detail
manualItem.manualHTML:
This page shows details of one or more community concepts. Sometimes, a message will appear telling you what you searched for.
Each area between beige banners represent one community concept. The area in white represents static information about the community, which is independent of party. The Concept definition is the name combined with the reference in which the name is described. These are listed here, as is a link to plots which have been interpreted as this community.
The area in grey represents information that is part of one party perspective, that is someone's opinion about a community (whether or not it is accepted, where in the hierarchy it fits, names to call it, and synonyms). Here, you can navigate throughout the hierarchy (to parents and children) with the parent and children links. Different people and organizations have different opinions about which communities should be grouped under which, thus the hierarchy is party-dependent. You can also link to synonyms and the NatureServe Explorer website for communities originating there.
Please note that it is possible for more than one party perspective to be listed per community.

manualItem.name: submit-comms
manualItem.manualHTML:
Currently, it is only possible to submit communities to VegBank through the XML Loader. We plan to implement online forms in the future.
Communities in VegBank were loaded from the EcoArt database, then from NatureServe Explorer. If you have other communities you want in VegBank, you will have to add these using VegBranch. For instructions on loading XML into VegBank, please see the Submit Plots topic. Please Note that to add any data to VegBank, or to annotate data, you will need to be registered and certified.

manualItem.name: supplemental-data
manualItem.manualHTML:
You can browse through Supplemental Data (that is data other than plots, plants, and communities) through the Home Page section .
VegBank views are generally of two types: summary and detail. Summary views example cover method summary are generally one table with a header row. Detail views offer more information and so each element takes up more rows example cover method details.
VegBank views are tightly interconnected, with links to related data scattered throughout each view. Please use the back button on your browser after clicking some links if you'd like to get back to your original search results.
Currently, only plots can be added to the datacart. We plan to add the capacity to add other items to the datacart soon, allowing you to search by groups of data in the datacart and to download supplemental data, as well.
You can search supplemental data with the search in the header or the General Search.

manualItem.name: general-search
manualItem.manualHTML:
The General Search works differently from other searches in VegBank. Other searches require you to search specific fields in order to find a certain kind of data, like plots, plants, or communities. The General Search is much less specific.
The General Search looks for keyword(s) in lots of fields and all kinds of data. This is a very wide funnel, but is a good starting point to find data. There are three places to start a general search:
The Header
The General Search Page
The Firefox Search Plugin
Case is ignored. Enter a word or words (or even part of a word1) into the search box and press the search button ("go" button on the header). VegBank will search all kinds of data2 for all3 the words you specified. This search works like most search engines. Enclose a phrase in quotes to look that phrase, i.e. "North Carolina" Acer could be used to look for plots in North Carolina with Acer mentioned. Note that North Carolina Acer would find plots in South Carolina that are in North Myrtle Beach, and have Acer mentioned.
All keywords for related data are included in the search. So, a plant name or place name will be part of the keywords for a plot.
To search more specifically, please use the advanced plot search, the plant search, or the the community search.
This is currently the only way to search Supplemental Data.
1By default, searches will match parts of words. If this becomes problematic, such as when Acerates is being found when you search for Acer, you can check the "Match Whole Words" check box on the General Search Page.
2 You can restrict the General Search in the header, by specifying what kind of data you're looking for, for example, plots or people. Select "anything" to remove search restrictions.
3 You can check the "match any word" checkbox in the main General Search page to search for items containing any word (separated by spaces) in the search box. Note that North Carolina is interpreted as two words, and thus everything that has North or Carolina in it will be found.

manualItem.name: data-in-vegbank
manualItem.manualHTML: A section of the Home Page shows how much data are currently stored in VegBank, for those who are curious. If you've just loaded data, and your plots don't seem to be included in the count, it's because this view is cached and has probably just not updated yet. You'll receive a receipt when you load plots, and that will tell you whether or not they loaded successfully.

manualItem.name: learn-about-vegbank
manualItem.manualHTML:
The "Learn About VegBank" section of the Home Page provides links to pages that will help you learn more about VegBank. Most of the links are self-explanatory. A few highlights:
Click What is VegBank for a general introduction to VegBank.
Our FAQ, or Frequently Asked Questions, answers some common questions we've had about VegBank. If you are new to VegBank, or plant ecology in general, you should read through the FAQ, especially What is a plot?, What is a community?, What is a Concept?, and Where VegBank gets its data.
You are currenltly reading the Tutorial, which is a step-by-step guide to most of VegBank's pages. This is very useful for new users. Click "Menu" at the bottom of this page to see a list of topics available.

manualItem.name: data-dictionary
manualItem.manualHTML:
Advanced Users:
The Data Dictionary provides detailed information about every table and field in the VegBank database. This is more useful for those who have already gained some experience with VegBank and wish to understand a particular table or field.
The index page of the data dictionary shows a list of tables and fields that one may select. Once a table or field has been selected, you will see a view of that table, with a field highlighted in orange if you selected a field. You may click on a field name to see that field in a detailed view.
In the detailed view, you will see the complete list of values for the field, if it is limited to a closed set of values (or the suggested values if the list is open, meaning this field may contain other values besides these recommended ones). You can also click on column headers or referenced fields for foreign keys to find out more about them.

manualItem.name: entity-relationship-diagram
manualItem.manualHTML:
Advanced Users:
An Entity Relationship Diagram (ERD) shows how different tables (entities) in a database are related. This is quite helpful for visualizing what the database contains and how these data are interconnected.
The VegBank ERD is a PDF file (you will need a reader for this, such as Adobe Acrobat Reader), which allows you to control zooming. Zooming out (~ 75%) is recommended for getting an overall picture of how all the tables relate; zooming in (120% +) is recommended for understanding how a smaller section of the database works.
click on a table in the ERD (the "hand" tool may need to be selected on the PDF toolbar in Adobe Acrobat Reader) to see that table in the data dictionary (described in previous topic).

manualItem.name: how-to-cite-vegbank
manualItem.manualHTML:
VegBank is an archival vegetation ecology database. Several different kinds of data may be cited: observation, party, reference, plantConcept, and commConcept. Each of these has an Accession Code in VegBank , which uniquely identifies it. This Accession Code may be used by you to cite VegBank and make reference to the particular data here.
The How to Cite Page describes how you can use these Accession Codes to cite data.
Understanding Accession Codes (advanced):
An example Accession codes for a plot-observation: VB.Ob.3801.GRSM261. Each code is broken into several pieces, split by periods (.).
VB represents the database which contains the data. Here, VB stands for VegBank. In the future there may be multiple VegBank databases, each of which may maintain different data.
Ob represents the table the data came from, using 2 letter codes (Ob stands for observation). Plots are best cited using an Observation Accession Code, because observations are the sampling of a plot at a time, which is generally what people want to cite.
3801 is the record number for the table (observation) in the database (VegBank).
GRSM261 is the confirmation value, which is not necessary for uniqueness, because the first three values will uniquely identify each element. But this value serves two other purposes.
First, it helps protect against typos. Without this value, typos such as VB.Ob.3810 would go undetected and users would see a plot other than the one they expected. With confirmation values, the typo code would be: VB.Ob.3810.GRSM261, which VegBank could not find, because it doesn't exist. Then, you could try to piece back what happened and perhaps get the correct plot after all. This may not always work, as plots could share the same confirmation code, but the confirmation value helps prevent this.
Second, it may provide a humanly readable handle which helps you to know what it is you're looking at. For observations, the authorObsCode is used as the confirmation value. Other tables use various fields which are somewhat unique.
In the future, Accession Codes used for citations will also include a date-time (GMT) after the first 4, such as 2003-04-18T14:43:27. This will be used to recreate the cited item as looked at that point in time.

manualItem.name: sitemap
manualItem.manualHTML: This most of the features and information available in VegBank at present. We also include some items on the sitemap that are planned in our future development. The most important pages are accessible through the header.

manualItem.name: contact
manualItem.manualHTML: We've included a contact page that shows you how to reach the VegBank staff if you need to.

manualItem.name: contribute-plot-data
manualItem.manualHTML: VegBank differs from many online databases in that our data comes from users who decide to share their plot data through VegBank. A brief certification form must be filled out to request certification, which is necessary before you contribute data. This helps ensure that the data you can view here comes from ecologists who both understand VegBank and assure us that their data, as represented in VegBank, are accurate.

manualItem.name: submit-plots
manualItem.manualHTML:
CERTIFICATION REQUIRED
To submit plots, the user must own the plot data or have permission to share this data online. Currently, plots may be only be submitted in our VegBank XML format. Generally, this will be generated by a program based on a database. We strongly recommend VegBranch
as the means for creating the XML file which will hold your data. Once you have generated the XML file, click the Submit Data link on the header to load this into VegBank.
On that page, enter the file name (or browse for it) on your computer of the XML file (or in public web space) and press the continue button. You'll receive an email receipt notifying you whether or not your plots loaded successfully, and if so, a link to see them online in VegBank.

manualItem.name: submit-with-vegbranch
manualItem.manualHTML:
CERTIFICATION REQUIRED
You can prepare data uploads to submit plots and other data with VegBranch. Please See the VegBranch Tutorial Topic for more on VegBranch.

manualItem.name: vegbank-xml
manualItem.manualHTML:
CERTIFICATION REQUIRED
While we recommend VegBranch as the tool to create an XML file containing your plots. However, you may create the file yourself from another program (advanced XML programmers). The XML specifications are listed on this page. If you have not programmed with XML files before, this will not be a feasible option for you. Instead, please use VegBranch.

manualItem.name: annotate-data-in-vegbank
manualItem.manualHTML:
CERTIFICATION REQUIRED
After a VegBank user submits data to VegBank, other users may search for and annoate this data. How this process works is described on the annotate data page. Please see the next few topics for how to add several different kinds of annotation.

manualHTML.p: For more on how annotation works, please see the annotation page.

Interpret a taxon by: Searching for plots, then clicking a plant name on a plot. In this detailed view [example] of a plant on a plot, there will be an "Interpret this Plant" link which will take you to the interpretation form.

The interpretation form consists of only very few fields, most of which are self-explanatory. You must find the Accession Code of the plant concept that you believe represents the taxon on the plot. There is a link to a pop-up query to help you find that concept. Once you have found the accession code, copy and paste it into the "plant concept acccession code" box.

The other fields relate to your interpretation, not the author's. Fit is how well the concept fits the taxon on the plot. If your taxon is large (genus or family), then fit is less likely to be high (unless the taxon on the plot included a lot of the genus, i.e. multiple species). Confidence is how sure you are about what you've done. This is NOT FIT. If you are certain that the fit is poor, your confidence should be high. Please fill in some notes as to why you interpreted the plant the way you did.

manualItem.name: interpret-a-plot
manualItem.manualHTML:
CERTIFICATION REQUIRED
For information on how annotation works, please see the annotation page.
Sorry, but this feature has not yet been implemented. Coming very soon!

manualItem.name: add-a-note
manualItem.manualHTML:
CERTIFICATION REQUIRED
For information on how annotation works, please see the annotation page.
Sorry, but this feature has not yet been implemented.
Coming in late 2005!

manualItem.name: tools
manualItem.manualHTML: VegBank offers several tools that are extensions of the website. These are listed in the Tools Section of the homepage. These tools are designed to interact with the VegBank website, but generally function outside it.

manualHTML.p: National Vegetation Classification Revision System (NVCRS) is an online vegtation type revision system for ecologists to submit their proposals for changes to the National Vegetation Classification System, for peer-viewers to evaluate submitted proposals and for panel members to make the final decisions to accept or decline a revision proposal.

VegBank is partnering with the NVCRS to help make the National Vegetation Classification an open process by which anyone (not just one private organization) may contribute to the definition of plant communities and the revision process. Please follow the link to the NVCRS for more information or to sign up.

manualItem.name: vegbranch
manualItem.manualHTML:
VegBranch is the client database for VegBank. That means that it is a database that you download and store on your computer. You can download it (at no cost) from the VegBranch Page. VegBranch is a Microsoft Access database which import data from other formats to prepare for submission to VegBank. It also offers several formats of data entry and export. Exporting to an XML through VegBranch is recommended way of submitting plots to VegBank. Unfortunately, VegBranch requires that you have MS Access 2000 or higher running on your machine. We hope to create a new version of VegBranch that will be platform independent in the future.
For more on VegBranch, please see the VegBranch Section of VegBank. Be sure to view the Overview, Loading Module Documentation, and Help Pages, too.

manualItem.name: normalizer
manualItem.manualHTML: The Normalizer is included in VegBranch, but is also available as a standalone MS-Access database. The Normalizer takes matrix formatted files and converts them into standard database files, which one header row. Please see the Normalizer Pages for more on how this works and to download it.

manualItem.name: nps-plots
manualItem.manualHTML:
The NPS PLOTS database can be imported into VegBranch with prebuilt functions that map fields from NPS-PLOTS to VegBranch. Metadata and problematic species and data errors must still be dealt with in VegBranch using the standard import forms.
A beta functionality to export INTO an NPS-PLOTS database has been completed, which allows data entry via NPS-PLOTS style forms and export to a PLOTS database which is required by some of our users grants. Please contact if you'd like to try this preliminary part of VegBranch.

manualItem.name: turboveg
manualItem.manualHTML: TurboVeg is a very popular European Plant Ecology database. We plan to write an import routine into VegBranch, similar to the NPS-PLOTS import routine (previous topic).

manualItem.name: firefox-toolbar
manualItem.manualHTML: Firefox and Mozilla browsers offer the ability to easily add search plugins. We've added a search plugin for these browsers that uses the General Search of VegBank. So, with this, you can type in words and press enter, and very quickly find data in VegBank.

manualItem.name: my-vegbank-account
manualItem.manualHTML: If you register with VegBank, you can have your own account, which lets you customize your experience at VegBank.org, similar to many other websites. Links to Your Account features can be found on the header . In your account, you can see the plots you've submitted, the options you've specified, and can link to forms for loggin in and out, registering, and certification. See the next few topics for details.

manualItem.name: register-as-new-user
manualItem.manualHTML:
We suggest that users register so that we can (1) track use of VegBank data, (2) maintain user profiles with preferences and use history, and (3) establish appropriate levels of certification and permissions for advanced functions. If you choose not to register, you may still use the site as a guest, but you will not be able to access certain functions (namely, anything that adds data to the database or adds any annotations).
You will sign onto VegBank using your email account and a password of your choosing. If your email account has already been registered, simply use the "forgot password" link and the password will be emailed to you. You will be prompted to login if you attempt to access a page in VegBank that requires registration or certification.
To become a Vegbank user, you must read and agree to the VegBank terms of use.

manualItem.name: update-user-profile
manualItem.manualHTML: You may change information about your personal user account. There is a link from that page to change your account password, too. If you forget your password, it can be emailed to you (see the next topic). Please keep your email address updated, as this will enable us to email you a password, if lost. We also hope to add features which allow you to receive email updates when data of interest are added to VegBank, or users annotate the data you submitted. Please see our Privacy Policy to assure you that we will not share this information, except for any information you provide during a certification-request which was noted public on that form.

manualItem.name: forgot-my-password
manualItem.manualHTML: If you have forgotten your password, use the forgot my password link on the Login page. Your password will be emailed to the email address you used to register with VegBank. If the email account you provided at VegBank registration has been closed, please use a different email account to register for a new account. If you wish to keep your old account due to certification or plots submitted, please contact the help desk using the contact link on the footer.

manualItem.name: request-certification
manualItem.manualHTML:
The ESA Vegetation Panel will provide a certification program for VegBank users. Certification is needed for at least two reasons.
1. The quality a user attaches to a plot observation in the archive is likely to vary with his or her perception of the workers who collected and submitted the data. In addition, users need a way to evaluate the credentials of an individual who has contributed an annotation (note) or interpretation (identification of a plot observation to community type, or a plant observation to species/taxon). One function of certification is to provide the user with a means of evaluating the ability of an unknown worker.
2. The quality of a plot in the archive will increase as additional information is added and interpretations are made. Not all users are qualified to add information to plot records, nor will all users understand the database and it uses well enough to know how best to add value to plot records. Certain types of annotation or interpretation will require user certification.
